sentences: Gregory Frank Raposo (born May 3, 1985) known professionally as Greg Raposo, is an American rock'n'roll singer and actor.
section: N/A

sentences: Raposo initially came to fame in the early 2000s as a member of the boy band Dream Street, but has subsequently branched out into a solo career as a rock singer.
section: N/A

sentences: His self-titled debut solo album Greg Raposo was released in 2003 and charted at #40 on the Independent Albums Chart in its opening week.
section: N/A

sentences: His follow up 2012 release Loss Love Life was released independently.
section: N/A

== Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: Gregory Frank Raposo was born in New York May 3, 1985 to Maryann and Octavio Raposo.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: When Greg was two years old, he began to develop a fascination with the guitar.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: When he was six years old, Mrs. Raposo decided that she was tired of having to buy more toy guitars because he kept breaking them, so she bought him his first real guitar and arranged for him to take guitar lessons with a private teacher.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: He was soon after entered into a talent contest.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: He won, singing an Elvis Presley song.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===

sentences: His aunt entered him on Star Search where he took second place and was referred to a talent agent.
section: == Life and career == | === 1985–1992: Early life ===
== Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===
== Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Raposo was cast in sixteen regional and national commercials for everything from Kit Kat bars to Crest toothpaste.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Then at nine, he requested to be allowed to sing and play guitar on-air during a local live recording of a radio show on WPLJ.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Deejay Scott Shannon agreed and Greg went on the air.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Shannon thought that Greg was very talented and from that day on was crowned as "The Elvis Kid".
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Greg appeared on WPLJ for three years.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: "The Elvis Kid" performed everywhere, including with The Jordanaires and DJ Fontana who were Elvis' real backup band.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Greg was the only child invited to perform at Graceland for the 20th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death (1997) by Priscilla Presley.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: In 1996, Raposo auditioned for 'Broadway on Broadway', an extravaganza of Broadway performers.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Greg got the honor of being the opener for the show and sang an original composition in front of fifty-thousand people.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: After opening for 'Broadway on Broadway', he was cast in an off-Broadway singing group called "The Broadway Kids", with whom he recorded two albums.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: During his time in The Broadway Kids Greg met Chris Trousdale.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: In 1998, both boys successfully auditioned for a group called "Boy Wonder".
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: "Boy Wonder" was disbanded for lack of interest from sponsors.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Raposo and Trousdale were later reunited for Dream Street.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Raposo was also involved with several charity and anti-substance abuse groups.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: This included: The Kids for Kids Project, Audrey Hepburn/Children's Fund, Young Plaza Ambassadors Club, Jerry's Kids, and Variety, the Children's Charity.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===

sentences: Raposo claims that Kids for Kids was the most fulfilling thing he has ever participated in.
section: == Life and career == | === 1993–1998: Career beginnings, "The Elvis Kid", and broadway ===
== Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street =
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===
== Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: Originally named 'Boy Wonder' (a name borrowed from the nickname of comic book character Robin from the Batman comics and films), Dream Street was put together by music producers Louis Baldonieri and Brian Lukow.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: Raposo along with Trousdale were already a shoe-in for the Dream Street auditions since they were the original member of 'Boy Wonder'.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: After casting two-hundred boys, Jesse McCartney, Frankie J. Galasso, and Matt Ballinger joined the group.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: Their eponymous debut album was released on July 10, 2001.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: It was certified Gold in the US by the RIAA peaking No. 1 on Billboard's Independent Albums chart and at No. 37 on the Billboard 200.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: The songs, "It Happens Every Time" and "I Say Yeah" were frequently played on Radio Disney.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: The boys soon made appearances to perform on various talk shows and television events including Maury and Ricki Lake.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: While the rising success of Dream Street was growing, tensions between the music producers and the boys' parents also arise.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: This led to a lawsuit that would force the members to disband.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: The final Dream Street release was the soundtrack album to the 2002 film The Biggest Fan, which starred Trousdale.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===

sentences: Raposo has appeared as himself in the film as well.
section: == Life and career == | === 1999–2002: Rise to fame and Dream Street ===
== Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney =
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===
== Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: He performed his first solo concert on October 13, 2002, at The Downtown in Farmingdale, New York.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: Tickets sold out in less than two hours and a second concert was issued for the same venue, which also sold out.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: He subsequently performed at several radio station multi-artist shows, solo acts, and as an opening act for several bands.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: On May 3, 2003, Raposo's first solo single, "Take Me Back Home", premiered on Radio Disney as a part of their "Music Mailbag" segment.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: It received positive ratings, and won a spot on the station's playlist with an 92% of the popular vote—setting records on RadioDisney.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: His second single, "Every Summer", premiered on the Radio Disney Music Mailbag on July 12, 2003, with 95% of the popular vote.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: Raposo's eponymous debut album was released on September 2, 2003.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: The album was in the top fifty on the Billboard Top Sales chart (#40) and was #67 on the Billboard Top HeatSeekers chart the week of its release.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: The second single from the album, "Every Summer", debuted on the RadioDisney Top Thirty Countdown on September 14, 2003, at spot #22.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: He debuted on the RadioDisney.com Top 3 with "Every Summer" on November 19, 2003, at the #3 spot.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: In November 2003, Greg embarked on his first national tour as a headlining act, co-heading with Stevie Brock for the RadioDisney Jingle Jam Tour, with former Dream Street bandmate Jesse McCartney opening.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: The tour hit nineteen cities across the United States and the average audience size was around 2000 people for each venue.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: Greg's first single, "Take Me Back Home", was officially added to the RadioDisney playlist on November 21, 2003.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: During 2004, Raposo would appear in a film Destination Fame.
section: == Life and career == | === 2002–2004: Solo career, Greg Raposo, and Radio Disney ===

sentences: Raposo ====
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Through years of various band formations, Raposo finally found what he was looking for in lead guitarist Nick Slobodskoy.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Nick was first a classically trained violinist, but that all changed when he was introduced to the music of Guns N' Roses and purchased his first guitar.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Nick formed rock band Floffus and later joined local band Brookside, sharing the stage with such national acts as Thursday, Taking Back Sunday, The Starting Line, Wheatus and Superdrag.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Drummer Lou Vecchio started playing drums from an extremely young age.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: This third-generation drummer cites his father, Louis Vecchio, among his many idols.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Endorsed by MRP Drums, Lou is recognized as one of the best drummers on Long Island originally form the famous NY band Unlikely Heroes  .
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: His tight rhythms and passionate playing brings a distinctive groove to the RAPOSO sound.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Bassist Jakey Lee grew up on classic rock.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: He was in Brookside for several tours and played with Nick.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: He had also done some studio sessions with Lou, and their chemistry was already there.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: Matching Lou's tight rhythms brought Jake into the fold as the final member of RAPOSO.
section: == Life and career == | ==== 2005–2006: Raposo ====

sentences: The third incarnation of RAPOSO were semi-finalists in the MTV2 Battle of the Bands for a spot on the RockBand II Tour and finished the voting process ranked in the top two.

sentences: Loss, Love, Life ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2012: Loss, Love, Life ===

sentences: After a three-year hiatus, Raposo returned to a solo career.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012: Loss, Love, Life ===

sentences: He released the independent album "Loss, Love, Life", in memoriam of his cousin Theresa Buccatello, on May 3, 2012, funded by a Kickstarter initiative.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012: Loss, Love, Life ===

sentences: The music video for his first independent single, "That Day", was produced in New York City and released online on May 15, 2012.
section: == Life and career == | === 2012: Loss, Love, Life ===

sentences: Reviews have praised "Loss, Love, Life" for being "genuine" and "not sounding like a slightly older boy band."

sentences: In the summer of 2012, Raposo featured on the Rock Camp Tour around New York, New Jersey, and Long Island.

== Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===
== Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===

sentences: Chris Trousdale tribute ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===

sentences: On June 2, 2020, Raposo's former Dream Street bandmate Chris Trousdale died at a hospital in Burbank, California, at the age of 34 due to complications from an unknown illness during the COVID-19 pandemic in California.
section: == Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===

sentences: It was later revealed that COVID-19 was the main complication of Trousdale's death.
section: == Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===

sentences: On June 11, 2020, on what would be Trousdale's 35th birthday, Raposo and his former Dream Street bandmates Jesse McCartney, Frankie Galasso, and Matt Ballinger reunited for a virtual performance of "It Happens Every Time" to pay tribute to Trousdale.
section: == Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===

sentences: This would be the first public appearance of Dream Street together as a group since the disbandment over the lawsuits prior.
section: == Life and career == | === 2020: Chris Trousdale tribute ===
